headline: Nana Bessie's Whoopie Pies
description: These classic chocolate whoopie pies filled with a thick layer of fluffy white frosting are a treasured family recipe from Grandma. They make great Christmas gifts.

video.description: The secret is in the fluffy, creamy filling.
video.name: Nana Bessie’s Whoopie Pies

name: Nana Bessie's Whoopie Pies

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.

To make cookies, beat 2/3 cup of vegetable shortening with 2 cups of sugar in a large mixing bowl with an electric mixer until the mixture is creamy. Beat in eggs and 2 teaspoons of vanilla extract until thoroughly combined. Whisk together 4 cups of flour, the cocoa powder, and baking soda until thoroughly mixed, then beat the flour mixture into the vegetable shortening mixture in several additions, alternating with the milk. Beat dough just until smooth.
Drop dough by tablespoon onto the prepared baking sheets, about 2 inches apart, making the cookies as round as possible. Recipe should yield about 48 cookies.

Bake in the preheated oven until the cookies are set in the middle, 15 to 20 minutes. Watch carefully to avoid burning the cookies. Allow cookies to cool for several minutes on baking sheets before removing to finish cooling on racks.

To make the filling, pour 3 cups of milk into a large saucepan over low heat, and whisk in 9 tablespoons of flour until smooth. Allow the mixture to come to a simmer, whisking constantly, until as thick and smooth as pudding, about 3 minutes. Place the thickened mixture into the refrigerator to cool, about 30 minutes.

In a large mixing bowl, beat 1 1/2 cup of vegetable shortening with the butter until thoroughly combined, then beat in 2 1/4 cup of sugar and 1 tablespoon vanilla extract until the mixture is thoroughly combined. Beat the cooled milk mixture into the butter mixture until smooth and fluffy, 1 to 2 minutes.
Choose 2 cookies of the same size, and spread a thick layer of filling on the flat side of a cookie; top with remaining cookie. Repeat with remaining cookies and frosting.

review.reviewBody:
After reading many reviews, I used the recipe for the cake portion of these whoopie pies, but not the filling. I’ve made this type of frosting from this recipe previously, neither my family or I really liked it. I used a buttercream instead, it worked very nicely. 
As far as the cakes in this recipe, they are lovely. They taste almost like the cake part of devil dogs, very yummy! Be sure not to overcook them, they are much better if they are still somewhat soft. 
I will definitely use this recipe for whoopie pies again, they were a big hit!

We thought the frosting was pretty ok, like most people. I wish I had read the reviews first because it was definitely too much frosting, especially because I only got 42 cookies instead of 48. Haha. Cakes are great, but definitely not as dark as the ones in the video. I’ll make them again.

JUST like my family recipe for the filling! I, however, beat this for 20+ minutes and it fluffs. Also added a bit of vanilla... 
I cheat and make the cakes themselves with cake mix - using 3/4c (or less) of water instead of 1 1/4c. cake mix *with pudding* gets sticky so avoid that kind. 
Use ice cream scoop to keep consistent sized cookies regardless of recipe used.
We like the dessert, especially my son. I made as directed and turned out great.
I add a pinch of salt to cookies and icing..Also,I use buttermilk instead of milk....

This is the best tasting whoppie pie I have ever made and eaten. You will not be disappointed if you decide to make this for your family. The recipe does not say to refrigerate after making but I leaned on the side of caution and will keep them cool since it is a milk base. The cooler temps do not affect the pie at all if you give it 5 minutes to warm up a little before eating.

I did like this recipe. Although, despite it made a lot of icing. Speaking of icing, I must say this icing is smooth. However I had to make some adjustments to it, for it was a little bland. As experience rules, I used powdered sugar instead of regular granulated sugar, much fluffier and smoother. As far as the cake goes it was fine.

Thought the cake was ok not the best, I had trouble with the frosting and didn't end up making it instead I put vanilla Icecream in the center 

I would recommend you to add melted chocolate o top if u are using Icecream as the chocolate whoppie pie tastes a little bland with out it

Also if it is hard to make perfect cirles for the pies so I just spread it out in an even layer on a greased cookie sheet and then cut squares ( could also cut into circles)
very good loved the cream inside nice soft cookie
The filling was awful.

The cakes were good, but the icing recipe was off. I agree with other reviewers that there was an excess of bland flavored icing. I tweaked it and the result was delicious...essentially I would follow the recipe but change the icing proportions as follows:
1 cup milk
3 tablespoons of all-purpose flour
3/4 cups vegetable shortening
3/4 cups butter
2 cups white sugar
1 Tablespoon of vanilla (or almond) extract
Cakes were ok but flavor was a little lacking. After reading reviews I just used canned frosting which worked great.
These were good! The cakes were kind of dry, but I suspsect that was because I replaced half the shortening with butter. Will be making these again

Filling was a total flop, but the cakes were really good. The filling was one of the most disappointing (and time consuming) of my baking endeavors. Will use my grandmothers recipe next time for the filling, but might stick with this recipe for the cakes. I definitely learned from this recipe though!
They were pretty good different from what I had expected but good though in a different way! Very chocolately!
I'd add some marshmallow fluff to the filling!

These are delicious, the only drawback for me was the richness of the filling. I really piled it on the cakes, and it was just too much. I will definately put less filling next time. I also used a tip from another whoopie recipe and wrapped each one in plastic wrap, then refrigerated them. They are good straight from the fridge.
Cakes were great!! Didn't care for the filling much. If you do decide to make this filling, I would suggest dividing it in half. Makes way too much, even with being generous.

I had a similar recipe years ago that i got from an old Pennsylvania Dutch cookbook but had lost it, much to my disappointment. I never liked the whoopie pies with the marshmallow cream filling because it was always way too sweet, so i'm really happy to find this recipe. Thanks!
The cakes came out great, but no one really liked the filling. The texture was perfect, but it was missing flavor. Followed recipe exactly. Might try this, but with different filling recipe.
